ul.li: Use integrals to find area between curves
Determine if a region should be integrated with respect to x or y in order to find the area between curves

ol.label: a
ol.li: Write (and evaluate) an expression to find the area between f(x) and the x-axis on [0,2]. Shade the area on the graph.
Write (and evaluate) an expression to find the area between g(x) and the x-axis on [0,2]. Shade the area on the graph.
Write (and evaluate) an expression to find the area between f(x) and g(x) on [0,2]. Do you need to shade the area?

image.description: This is the graph of f(x) on the interval [0,2] with the area between the curve and the x-axis shaded

li.p: The area is found via the integral \ds \int_0^2 f(x)\, dx, and the area is \dfrac{16}{3}.

image.description: This is the graph of g(x) on the interval [0,2] with the area between the curve and the x-axis shaded

li.p: The area is found via the integral \ds \int_0^2 g(x)\, dx, and the area is 2.

image.description: This is the graph of f(x) and g(x) on the interval [0,2] with the area between the curves shaded

li.p: The area is found by combining the answers from (a) and (b): \ds \int_0^2 f(x)\, dx - \int_0^2 g(x)\, dx, so the area between the curves is \dfrac{10}{3}. We don't necessarily need to shade the area, because if we did (a) and (b) on the same graph, the overlapping area is the area being excised.

theorem.title: Area Between Curves
theorem.p: Let f,g be continuous functions, and let f(x)\geq g(x) for all x in [a,b]. The area A of the region bounded by the curves y=f(x),y=g(x) and the lines x=a,x=b is given by A = \ds \int_a^b (f(x)-g(x))\, dx
